sp.p: Wer't not for modesties sake I would have my peny worths out of thy flesh.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.l: The hangman will rid us of that care; beggerly slave!
Why dost not laugh at him 〈◊〉 ?

sp.speaker: Vra.
sp.l: I could shed tears for thee poor Lucius.
Though many moneths thou couldst indure my gri • f,
One day seems long till I yeeld thee relief.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Is then all love and pity banished? In lieu then of the good thou stand'st possest by me, grant me but one nights being in thy house, thou see'st tis late, and I unfurnished of means and credit.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p: Would one night save thy life, restore thy name and thy degraded honour, I would not grant it, for know I hate thee more, then all thy wealth in • orc'd me love before.

sp.speaker: Surd.
sp.l: You are no who • ?

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.l: So let's in if longer you stay here,
I will provide you of a Harbinger.

sp.speaker: Gull.
sp.p: You shall have a lodging at the cost of the Parish if you stay a little longer.

sp.speaker: Surd.
sp.p: Baud, blood-sucker Canniball.

sp.speaker: Vra.
sp.p: Afflicted man! I that for comfort sought thy company, could now afford some pity unto thee.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Ill destined Lucius, but in vain's complaint, then tell me Surdo, what cure canst thou apply unto my miseries?

sp.speaker: Surd.
sp.p: Such as the world gives to men in distresse. As I am a Courtier I must leave you.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: How leave me?

sp.speaker: Surd.
sp.p: Would you not have me follow the example of my betters? I promised you to serve you only as you were a Lord; and so I have done, and will till I see you at the gallowes, and thither you shall have followers enough.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Wilt thou not help to find my wife out then?

sp.speaker: Surd.
sp.p: Ile see what I can do. Oyes! did any manner of man take up a woman child, of the age of 22. lost for want of a husband, let them look into her mark, and if they finde her a Virgin bring her to the Hangman.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Ingratefull groom, doest mock my misery?

sp.speaker: Surd.
sp.p: Are you such an asse to think she'l be found to save you from Hanging, that have left her swimming all this while? she has more hope of her widowhood then so; the old saying is, Marry a widow whose husband was hanged; and then she cannot upbraid you with them • Ile see if I can find her and put it in practise. Farewell, I will look to hear from you by the next new Ballad; pray Iove it be to a good tune, and come off bravely to the life, t'will be to your own com • ort and credit of your followers, to see and hear so many bear parts in your death.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Contemn'd and left of all! where are my parasites now?

Honours shadowes that seem to move with an obsequious right, as if they were in • eperably tyed unto our persons. When the truth is, their motion is from the sun, which being done once, we are lest naked. Why should I blame this world then,
sp.l: Since means and honour sway the greatest men?
For give me one that ere lov'd virtue poore,
Shew me an Userer charitable, or an honest whore.
I cannot Flavia with just cause condemn thee.
It is the leaden waight of time that moves thy hate,
And with a violent hand doth force thy soul
To this observing world, for well thou knowest,
Wert thou as chast and fair as the Greekish dame,
Fam'd for her twice ten winters constancie,
And hadst no foil to put thy virtues off,
Thou might'st spin out thy daies to get thee food,
Or turn base prostitute, and sell thy blood,
At every comers price.

sp.speaker: Vra.
sp.l: Where night I find this most unhappy man!
Whose grief will not permit my jealous soul
To trust him with the night: Oh! did he know
How much beyond my self I prize his love;
T would move him to afford me pity, if not love.
But see where suiting with his fortunes, on the ground
He has cast himself, could we our fates foreknow,
He had kept the happy mean, not Iain so low.
My honour'd Lord why with so hard an eye,
Do you behold your friends?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Thou doest forget thy self, I am poor, and poverty,
When none else will do't, makes all men fly.

sp.speaker: Vra.
sp.l: You much mistake me Sir, I am Castadora
Yet cannot choose but love you, whose sympathy
Speaks mine own woes: pray Sir accept this.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: O! tell me true,
Did not Flavias hand commit this charge to thee?

sp.speaker: Vra.
sp.l: Can you yet think she loves you Sir, whose hate
Has reacht a height so far above her sex?
Or is your weaknesse such to love her still?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: My constancy is such I ever shall.
Alas! tis not her hate but fear to suffer in my disgrace, tis her
want that moves her thus to my injury.

sp.speaker: Vra.
sp.l: These are the effects
Of lust whose seat is in the bloud and sway'd by that
As by the nourishing food, whereas love
Having her residence only in the soul;
And setling her affections once is not more moy'd by
Any outward accident then are our thoughts by
Captiving our bodies.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Thou speakest beyond a woman.

sp.speaker: Vra.
sp.l: You have a wife Sir, or it seems you had one,
Though by your much ingratitude undone.
Compare these two, the strumpee and your wife,
One seeks your death, the other gives you life.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Thy words do trouble me, I am not well.

sp.speaker: Vra.
sp.l: Alas! how can you Sir, you are in hell?
Tyed to the flames of an inchanting Harlot.
Pardon me Sir, if beyon • modesty,
I presse a strangers ear, in whom I see
My own sad fate, answer me one demand.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Freely speak what ere it be.

sp.speaker: Vra.
sp.l: What one particular
Most moves your love unto this creature?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Her beauty which alone I would injoy.

sp.speaker: Vra.
sp.l: But never did.
What pleasure has the Userer in seeing
Anothers gold he cannot hord? or what
Particular happinesse gives that which every day,
Man for a Pistollet may make purchase on.
O! think that willingly you would not wear
The garments of another; nor lay your body
In the common bed of a suspected Harlot.
Think how much more you should abhor to mix
Your blood with an adulterate curtezan;
Wash in a leprous bath; a strumpets womb;
And she your love is such another.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Impossible!

sp.speaker: Vra.
sp.l: How if I make it apparent?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I should die willingly, and think my tortures
Too gentle for so foule a change.

sp.speaker: Vra.
sp.l: Attend me then,
Here are three duckets all the store 〈…〉 me.
What will you say, if for this gold you obtain,
To lie with her this night.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: As I am Lucius, whom she so contemns.

sp.speaker: Vra.
sp.l: The same; Imbrace her lustfull wast, receive
As much content as ever, yet in the morn,
She shall reject your sight with loathed scorn.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Make me so happy in my misery;
My soul shall blesse thee.

sp.speaker: Vra.
sp.l: And if I do not may I lose my hopes;
Come saddest soul, your doubts Ile not prolong,
Thus honest wives avenge their husbands wrong.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: How like you fair this solitary life?

sp.speaker: Adell.
sp.l: As shipwrackt men the shore, or prisoners liberty.
I never thought a good in life to be,
Untill I found it here.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: This your content doth bring in to my minde
Those dayes that Cavus lived upon his plain,
Unhappy Courtier, yet a happy swain.
Me thinks I now do hear his well-tun'd pipe
That drew the covetous ear of listning shepheards
To hear him chant his passed misery.
But I forget my self and stay too long,
Our supper's yet to kill, and night drawes on.

sp.speaker: Adell.
sp.l: You need not make such hast, our store's not spent;
Here's enough left: small viands serve content.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: But time cals forth, and promise liberall prey.
I must be gone, and if my horn you hear,
Think I have sped. I promise thee rich cheer.

sp.speaker: Adell.
sp.l: Take your own way, why now I thank thee fate,
Thou hast made a double mends for my lost state,
In stead of honours and a marriage bed,
To chast thoughts and content my soul is wed.
Vain world I hate the stead of thy flattery;
Heaven is my Book, virtue my company.

sp.speaker: Osw.
sp.l: Where should I seek out death, or find some means
To stop the gaping jawes of famine, I could on equall
Termes incounter with a Tigre, whose rage hath
Suck't her dry. Ingratefull hunger that feeds upon
His bowels, whose want denies him sustenance.
Thou wound'st me more then all mine enemies. But
See some Angel, yet her face speaks her woman. Meat!
Should Devils guard it, thus would I reach and eat.

sp.speaker: Adel.
sp.p: Amazement to my soul, how greedily he feeds, twas want sure forc'd him hither, if so I am glad our poverty supplies him: Oh! did he know who with a licorish palat feeds to surfet, how many empty souls would be made happy in what he vomits; or felt one dayes torture of piercing hunger, with what temperate hand he would injoy these natures medicines! food is no other.

sp.speaker: Osw.
sp.p: So I feel my self in reasonable temper now. But I forget my happinesse, here's a better course. Pardon me beauty, that I scaped so fair a mark as your lips, but now Ile make amends.

sp.speaker: Adel.
sp.p: What mean you Sir?

sp.speaker: Osw.
sp.p: Nay I know you will plead chastity, tis the common fault of your sex, you have been some under vessell, waiting woman, and faln into the Butlers hands, had an untimely broaching, and now are laid aside here for ripening.

sp.speaker: Adel.
sp.p: What do you take me for?

sp.speaker: Osw.
sp.p: A woman made for the use of man.

sp.speaker: Adel.
sp.l: I am a haplesse woman,
Wrackt at Sea, and cast upon this shoar.

sp.speaker: Osw.
sp.p: Did not I tell you, ye had a leak; Come, come, leave circumstance, thou seest I am mortall, and thou art flesh and bloud, born to fall and therefore let's down together; nay, nay, do not resist.

sp.speaker: Adel.
sp.p: Not resist? know brutish creature, I am too well provided to lose mine honour, so long as this frail flesh which we call life can ransome it. Villain keep off! chast Lucrece shall be my president.

sp.speaker: Osw.
sp.p: So I would have her, lie with Tarquin first, and then kill thy self after if thou hast a minde to't. Lucretia she was the first cunning whore that ever made a fool of a Cuckold, when she saw the morning, her night villany was discovered, to prevent the fire fell upon the sword; but since you'l needs be stabbed, Ile help you.

sp.speaker: Adel.
sp.l: Prevented! if there be a power that helps
Distrest chastity, rescue a spotlesse maid.

sp.speaker: Osw.
sp.p: She should be a maide, she's so unwilling to her businesse. But since you force me to enter into bonds with you, Ile make you seal to the Articles of agreement, ere I have done with you.

sp.speaker: Adell.
sp.l: Help, help, if I have deserv'd thine anger Heaven,
Oh let it fall at once! Let one death expiate.

sp.speaker: Osw.
sp.p:
She should be a sinner, death's so often in her mouth. What's
here? Epistles? To the high & mighty Prince Ferdinand. From whence? Yours Valer •
of Sicily. We have sent you here our Letter. daughter—Fortune, thou hast return'd amends for all my wrongs. Revenge, I wonot keep thee fasting one minute longer.

sp.speaker: Adel.
sp.p: Heaven thou art just; now Monster doe thy worst,

sp.speaker: Osw.
sp.p: Beyond Hels torture; What Villaine blows that Horn?

sp.speaker: Adell.
sp.p: A vertuous Woodman, who with his followers.

sp.speaker: Osw.
sp.p: His followers? Nay then I am trapt, the bellowing Oxe that with his grones did fright the Earth carryed not half that torture in't, I shall dissolve through fear.

sp.speaker: Adell.
sp.p: The basenesse of thy guilt, unworthy wretch! Yet know how worthy merit stands; I pity thee, Distract thy self no further, by my chast bloud, I'le set thee free, so hence • orth to this Wood thou wilt become a stranger.

sp.speaker: Osw.
sp.l: Hell swallow me else.

sp.speaker: Adell.
sp.l: I'le take your oath, unbind me first, then fall
To your meat, with as good stomach as before.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Recall your spirits, grief-afflicted men.
Time may restore those honours he hath borrowed.
'Tis but to try how you will bear it; nor shall I think it my least happinesse to have been Author of your change.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: Your vertuous arguments have overcome us.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Now Lady I have brought you: Ha, what stranger's that?

sp.speaker: Adell.
sp.l: A miserable almost famisht man,
He hardly could speak well when he came in,
His body was so weak, his mind so ill.

sp.speaker: Osw.
sp.p: Shee'l spoyl all; I was a poor souldier in these wars, and have been in some reputation with our King. I have been troublesome to this Gentlewoman: I would fain bee unmannerly, having filled my belly, be out of this Forrest.

sp.speaker: Adell.
sp.l: His guilt admits no trust, pray give him free conduct,
I'le force your stay, since we have met thus happily.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: We will not part till supper, no place I see
But gives us means to practice charitie.
What wants in fare, your welcome shall supply,
Make good my promise Lady.

sp.speaker: Adell.
sp.l: With a willing heart.
If you knew all, you'd say I had reason for't.

sp.speaker: Osw.
sp.l: Hell choke you with your Supper. But may these two be,
Sileus and Leonardo, that helpt to disthrone me?
What new turn of State has forc'd them hither?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I'le question him, it may be he can resolve us, if Oswell lives;
Me thought I heard thee name thy dependence on the banisht King.

sp.speaker: Osw.
sp.p: I did hang on him as others did, as long as he had nap, you ha my meaning; came you not from Court?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Against our wils; for know, we are banisht thence by unmindful Ferdi • and, who for one bad, has quite forgot the many goods he still enjoys by us.

sp.speaker: Osw.
sp.l: I know't too well; Hell take you for't.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Leaving our merits; Let it suffice
He turn'd us down, that by our aid did did rise.
Can you resolve Sir, if Oswell live?

sp.speaker: Osw.
sp.l: And if I could, think'st I would betray him! I'de suffer first.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Protest no further, there's none here means him lesse good then your self.

sp.speaker: Osw.
sp.p: This fals out to my wish; a word with you Gentleman: suppose Oswell lived, and by your aid might repossesse his Diadem, would you prove honest?

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.p: As Heaven to virtue!

sp.speaker: Osw.
sp.p: Then know I am the man, and to regain my Crown want only but your assistance.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.p: Command us as your Vassals.

sp.speaker: Osw.
sp.p: As our friends, and those that shall have equall shares with us. First then know this woman is Valerius his daughter.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: The woman of this cave.

sp.speaker: Osw.
sp.p: The same, sent hither to be matcht with Sigismond, and shipwrackt in her passage, fell upon this shore.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.p: A most strange accident.

sp.speaker: Osw.
sp.p: 'Tis her disgrace or death must raise our hopes.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: How is this to be made possible?

sp.speaker: Osw.
sp.p: Thus; my self not taking notice of her birth, will charge her to the State for companying in lustful action with this woodman, which seconded by you, will seem so clear, that being returned with shame, or here with death paying her forfeiture, her father that overwhelm'd our state in just revenge bears us up agen.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.p: A most unheard of Villany.

sp.speaker: Osw.
sp.p: Doe you demur upon't?

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.p: We only want disguise, that and 'tis done.

sp.speaker: Osw.
sp.p: Here's gold to furnish you, this night I'le raise the neighbouring Village to apprehend 'um, make you hence and fail not to morrow to meet me in the Senate.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Our lives be gag'd, if we one minute misse,
Be this the last day of our happinesse.

sp.speaker: Osw.
sp.l: Your wishes be your own. Thou Queen of Fate,
Forbear thy restlesse motion but one hour,
Revenge is mine, Oswel's above thy power.

div.head: ACT. V.

sp.speaker: Vra.
sp.p: HAve I not kept my promise? did you not finde her base and mercenary?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: She is as all the world is mercenary,
Except thy self chast vertuous Castadora.

sp.speaker: Gull.
sp.l: But art sure he has no more gold?

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: Not an Asper; but I'le try, come you dissembling wanton, thou dost not know how I love thee, • ast ne'r a toy, a Ring, nor Jewel lest?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Pardon sweet Flavia, I ha not any, yet such is thy impulsive and attracting beauty, I can as well live without free ayr, as be debarred thy presence.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p: How's this, my presence?

sp.speaker: Gull.
sp.p: The fellow's desperate, he would fain be hang'd at our dore, we want no sign; good Wine needs no bush, we have custome enough already.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Thou dost but put this trick on me to try me,
Thy last nights love shew'd thy affection to me.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p: Affection! marry foh—I would not end • re such another nights torment; Pack hence, or call an Officer.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Thy worst foul Monster! I will not leave this place,
Wast thou as high in malice as in lust,
Here will I end my life, to prove Heaven just.

sp.speaker: Vra.
sp.l: Let me intreat you for this day forbear him.

sp.speaker: Gull.
sp.p: Out upon thee pu • i • anical filth, we may thank thee for this, that preferst the Cart before the Horse; turn Procurer, before th' art past procreation.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.l: This young B • wd will confound all our doings.
I shall set you in with a mischief.

sp.speaker: Vra.
sp.p: Thou hast done thy wrost already, and my miseries in spite of thee shall end, this hower doth gain.
My Lucius love, or kils me with disdain.

sp.speaker: Gull.
sp.p: You will not go then?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Not stir from hence.

sp.speaker: Gull.
sp.p: Look to the door daughter while I go for the Constable; Wouldst make a vaulting schoole of our house? thou ma • st hang thy self and thou wilt, but not here neither, yet if thou hast a mind to't, Ile go fetch a Hangman.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.l: She tels you true; this in a circle followes,
Fools and knaves nourish us, and we the gallowes.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Monsters in nature! my apprehensive thoughts
Present a thousand tortures, the least of which
Wounds more, then the bloudiest E • ecut •• ner.
Thou tell-tale conscience, cease thy b • uling clamors,
Here's that shall stop thy throat, yet now I think on't,
My poor Vrania dyed a lingring death;
Each thought whereof like to a greedy Vulture,
Feeds on my tyred heart Thou discont • n • ed ghost,
Where ere thou wandrest stay thy restlesse course.
Behold thy most ingratefull husbands bloud,
Siting the thirsty earth. And thus V • ania, I boldly come to thee.

sp.speaker: Vra.
sp.p: And thou art welcome, as heaven to miserie. Mistake me not, I am V • ania, she that in this shape, persued thy wished • ight, attending this blest hour.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l:
Vrania!
• hame and my joyes at once confound me.
• anst thou forgive my wrongs?

sp.speaker: Vra.
sp.p: As freely as I wish forgivenesse of my sins, say but thou lovest me, I have double interest for my sorrow.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Love thee! I am thy vassall, my joyes come on so fast,
I fear they are too violent to last.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p: I think here comes a 〈◊〉 to remove you How' • this, Lucius and my maid so familiar? impudent strumpet, Ile tear the flesh off thy face.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Perpetuall hag, take this for't.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.l: Devils and • uries! I am slain.

sp.speaker: Vra.
sp.l: Alas! what hast thou done?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Nothing but what my life must answer, flie my V • ania,
Though thou for gav'st me, heaven will not;
By what thou hold'st most dear, abandon me.

sp.speaker: Vra.
sp.l: No, Should the racks and tortures presently
Be fixt unto my limbs.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Thou add' • t to my afflictions, if prayers
Will not prevail • Ile fl • e and leave thee.

sp.speaker: Vra.
sp.l: Rather of life then of this sight bereave me;
Know I will accuse my self as chief • st actor in this Murther,
It thou makest motion to go without me.

sp.speaker: Gull.
sp.p: See, this is the fl • sh flie I told you of, open that box, you may swear l • wfully you took no bribe of me, Constable do your office, Oh my daughter, Constable, my daughter!

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: How came this murther?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: This bloudy hand did do it.

sp.speaker: Vra.
sp.p: Set on by me.

sp.speaker: Gul.
sp.p: Let me tear her eyes out.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: By all that may be sworn by, she is free; the act is only mine.

sp.speaker: Gull.
sp.p: Most unnaturall villain to thrust a woman into the body thus unmanly, I will have both your blouds for't.

sp.speaker: Vra.
sp.p: Mine, he is innocent.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Mine, I desire it.

sp.speaker: Gull.
sp.p: Nay, nere st • ive, Ile hang you both I warrant you, my daughter was not unknown to some of the bench, and if they would not speak for her in such a case as this, would they might never have good of womans flesh. Oh my daughter! my chast and virtuous daughter.

div.stage: Enter Sigismond and Catzo as a Lady.

sp.speaker: Sigis.
sp.p: Thou art a Lady fair one.

sp.speaker: Catz
sp.p: I, a horrible painted one.

sp.speaker: Sigis.
sp.p: And a mighty great one, and therefore Ile court thee.

sp.speaker: Catz.
sp.p: Tis beyond the art of man to court me fair, I am not to be dealt withall in that kind, and therefore keep off, I am not for your turn, keep off saucy jack.

sp.speaker: Sigis.
sp.p: Not for my turn? why I am a Prince, and will ingirt thy brow, thy Ivory brow, with stones as precious.

sp.speaker: Catz.
sp.p: Stones! you can do no good upon me with your stones.

sp.speaker: Sigis.
sp.p: Grant me but assurance of thy love, Ile dart against Ioves thunder, my rivall Iove, whose bolt did cleave my heart, threw and threw, and made a bro • dway to my brain, when I last courted thee in yonder thicket.

sp.speaker: Catz.
sp.p: Oh horrible! he has got the true propertie of a Lover, he can lie bravely. Court me in yonder thicket?

sp.speaker: Sigis.
sp.p: Why? hast thou forgot ray sweet duck, look on me my pigsnie, cast but one smile, one gentle smile upon me.

sp.speaker: Catz.
sp.p: Some smile! I cannot smile for laughing.

sp.speaker: Sigis.
sp.p: Well remember this, you will not afford me a sheeps eye, say no more, nay nere intreat, thou getst not a kisse, a look, nor a touch, nor a feel, nor a bit of my thums length.

sp.speaker: Catz.
sp.p: That's but short allowance for a Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Sigis.
sp.p:
I must to her again, you do not love me, you do not.
Alas! I am ignorant of your tricks, you have forgot, Since you and I plaid last at Maw, when your Ace of harts could not command my Knave of diamonds, til you were glad to lay your five fingers on't.

sp.speaker: Catz.
sp.p: Maw! fie upon him, what a noddy is this?

sp.speaker: Sigis.
sp.p: You have forgot since I talk't baudy with your Ladyship by moonshine, and how you swore you dream't of me, till you tickled again, and ever since doated on me with the very conceit of the dream, and now I will make your Ladyship kneel for a kisse, nay humble thy self, and I wo'not come over thee.

sp.speaker: Catz.
sp.p: Fie, fie, never had Gentlewoman such a suitor. Now by my poating stick; a fit oath for a chambermaid, you shall have him court me in all the true Elements of a drunkard, Fox-like, Lyon-like, and last, Maudlin-like, and so turn all his smiles into tears.

sp.speaker: Sigis.
sp.p: Not yet? will she not stoop? I must close with her, Come, come, I know you swell now, you grow so plumpe about the lips, suppose I should vouchsafe to kisse this chop cherry now.

sp.speaker: Catz.
sp.p: I scorne to kisse I can assure thee.

sp.speaker: Sigis.
sp.p: Disdain a Prince, a Lyon, curtrash parboil'd stuff. What's woman but a hollow vessell, an Aquavite bottle, a washing tub, a box? What is your Ladyship proud of?

sp.speaker: Catz.
sp.p: Of my Virginity Sir.

sp.speaker: Sigis.
sp.p: Ile try what kind of stuff your Ladyships Virginitie's made of.

sp.speaker: Catz.
sp.p: Thou wilt not ravish me, wilt thou?

sp.speaker: Sigis.
sp.p: By Mars his standard but I will.

sp.speaker: Catz
sp.p: By Venus buckler but thou shalt not.

sp.speaker: Sigis.
sp.p: Thou wilt not draw I hope.

sp.speaker: Catz.
sp.p: But I will, and defend my maiden honour with my life.

sp.speaker: Sigis.
sp.l: Put up fair maid, thy chastity orecomes my spleen,
Forgive me gentle Love, and I will weep my self to water.

sp.speaker: Catz
sp.p: That may be, for your brain swims I am sure, What an asse is this to be in love with me? I am no Lady, Sir, I am your man Catzo.

sp.speaker: Sigis.
sp.p:
Keep off, I shall orewhelme thee else, dost not see me swi •
and tumble mountain high? thou art Pinace, art thou?

sp.speaker: Catz.
sp.p: A kind of a flie-boat, there's a storme toward, my best is to put into harbour.

sp.speaker: Sigis.
sp.l: Sea room enough or we are lost, amain, amain,
Now up, now down again.

sp.speaker: Catz
sp.p: I am sure I have a leak already, help, help, help.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: What means this out • ry?

sp.speaker: Catz.
sp.p: I think he has thrust out my bottome, I shall never live to prove the old proverb true, a young Courtier and an old begger, I have had so many maims in his service.

sp.speaker: Sigis.
sp.p: Neptune has laid the storme, how calm's the sea now? how silent the windes? all's done, all's done.

sp.speaker: Catz.
sp.p: All's one for that you, shall not draw me to sea with you again.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: How camest thou thus attired?

sp.speaker: Catz.
sp.p: He said he would make a Lady on me, but as many Knights do, he has made a poor one of me, he began very hotly. But at last he coold me over head and ears, He handle a Lady!

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: This makes me thinke that love was the original • of this untimely extasie, didst never hear him speak of some strange beauty?

sp.speaker: Catz.
sp.p: He spoke too lately with me, and now I remember me, I left him in the wood with a good handsome Female, and when I found him again, he was as mad as a Hart in rutting time.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: Her sight sure did transport him. What newes Vincentio?

sp.speaker: Vinc.
sp.p: No great newes, onely a woodman and a maid accus'd of soul lust, this day receive their doom.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: Where were they taken?

sp.speaker: Vinc.
sp.p: In an obscure Cave within the Forrest.

sp.speaker: Sigis.
sp.l: That maid would I fain deal withall, command her hither.
Why dost not fetch her?

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Be patient, thou shalt along with us.
Dost know the face that late ith • orrest lost you?

sp.speaker: Catz.
sp.p: I have cause to know it, they talke of countenances, I got more by that face in an hour, then the best countenance ith' Court will get me in an age, though I were Usher to the best Lady of them all.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: My heart presages; Good heaven work thy will;
When we least hope, the heavens prove kindest still,
Sirra bring him along.

sp.speaker: • Catz.
sp.l: Come Sir, will you jog into the Garden?

sp.speaker: Sigis.
sp.l: You'l bring me to the Lady then.

sp.speaker: Catz.
sp.l: Yes presently, as soon as ever we can overtake her.

div.stage: Enter Gisbert as a Senator, with others, Oswell, Alexis, Adellezia, Officers.

sp.speaker: Gisb.
sp.l: Stand forth Alexis, though my soul doth tell me,
Thy thoughts are cleere from foul 〈◊〉 ,
Yet since thy Accuser by just course of Law
Pursues thy life, thou must endure the hand of peerless Justice.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: I crave no other,
Let equall combat prove us worthy death,
Or else just vengeance stop his perjur'd breath.

sp.speaker: Osw.
sp.l: I seale to thy Request; if in one houre
Two witnesses besides my selfe doe not make good
This accusation.

sp.speaker: Gisb.
sp.l: Your offer stands confirm'd. Officer at Armes
If ere the appointed time, these witnesses
Make no Appearance, bring into the Lists
Those Combatants equally prepar'd.

sp.speaker: Officer.
sp.l: It shall be done.

sp.speaker: Gisb.
sp.l: Although my place forbids to doe thee other Right
Alexis, yet this comfort I will give thee, which stands for all,
No power were just, if guiltlesse men should f • ll.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: I have no other hope, who beares a spotless brest,
Doth want no comfort else, how ere distrest.

sp.speaker: Adel.
sp.l: That speakes our happinesse, for spite of destiny
We can nor live nor dye unhappily,
How ever Ile conceale my parentage.

sp.speaker: Gisb.
sp.l: What other cause depends to crave our hearing?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: Bring em forth; away with em.

sp.speaker: Vinc.
sp.l: How now, what noyse is this?

sp.speaker: Gul.
sp.l: Justice, let me have Justice Noble Senators.

sp.speaker: Gisb.
sp.l: Speak freely, woman 〈…〉 .

sp.speaker: Gul.
sp.l: Behold the bloody 〈…〉 .

sp.speaker: Gisb.
sp.l: How Lucius one of em? vile wretch;
Doest thou not know this day doth end thy life,
If thou shalt faile to finde thy hapless wife.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: That sentence thus is voyd, 〈…〉
Your daughter and my wife.

sp.speaker: Gisb.
sp.l: My daughter.

sp.speaker: Vra.
sp.l: Oh thinke that I am lost still, or that
You ne're were happie in the injoyment of a 〈◊〉
For know I stand guilty of this abhorred 〈◊〉 .

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: She wrongs her innocent soule, 'twas this hand did it
In just mov'd Anger.

sp.speaker: Vra.
sp.l: But 'twas I that bid him,
And that in Law is principall.

sp.speaker: Gul.
sp.l: Between em both I have lost my daughter;
A very chast Virgin and a vertuous.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: A noted whore, a Curtezan.

sp.speaker: Gisb.
sp.l: Divided soule, in what amazement stand'st thou?
On this hand Justice stands, but here a father;
Nature thou art powerfull in me; Immaculates Robes,
You shall not blush at my partiality.

sp.speaker: Vinc.
sp.l: What meane you Sir?

sp.speaker: Gisb.
sp.l: To be a man, a father, oh my Vrania!

sp.speaker: Vinc.
sp.l: This violent passion needs not, Sir possesse your seat againe.

sp.speaker: Gisb.
sp.l: It suites not with my fortunes, vouchsafe
Me leave to plead her cause, you worthy Judges;
Behold three lives layd in a doubtfull scale,
'Gainst which a strumpets Lust the ballance swayes;
Three worthy lives, if age and fate deny
To make mine miserable, which if your gentler hands
Refuse to poise, are lost, and must pay the price
Of an adulteresse blood. Oh thinke what a whore is!
A creature onely shap't like woman, that we might see
In that faire foile ' • est her deformitie.
The wombe of sinne from whence all horrid crimes,
As Rivolets from the Sea, derive their streames;
The Devills warehouse, for though we voyd all snares,
This surely takes, and here he vends his wares:
Which no shop else wu'd utter, hence avarice,
Pride, pale murder, all black deeds doe rise; besides,
Thinke how she stands in Law, to whom deny'd
A Christian Buryall, this Law by which we are try'd;
Oh let it not exact such payment then,
For those deserve not common Rights of men.
This is the onely fa • our I doe crave,
Judge her unworthy life as of a grave.

sp.speaker: Vinc.
sp.l: Your Arguments are forcible; onely let's know
The Motives to her death.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Her sensuall rage
Brought her into the place, where much unlook'd for
Joy forc'd one embrace,
The wretch at sight hereof orecome with spleene,
Or hatefull Jealousie, with violent hands
Did seise my wife, which sight on sodaine rais •
My just incensed blood, that with one stroake
Her cursed life unhappily I tooke.

sp.speaker: Gisb.
sp.l: Make it your owne case, thinke how free they stood,
In height of their owne Joyes from others blood.

sp.speaker: Vinc.
sp.l: The case is plaine she sought her owne death
Willfully, and seeking her owne ill
We judge them free, now take your place agen.

sp.speaker: Gisb.
sp.l: Beare witnesse, I have playd a fathers part.

sp.speaker: Vinc.
sp.l: A carefull father.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: One most kinde and loving.

sp.speaker: Gisb.
sp.l: Let me embrace you both; farewell; think here
Your father dyes, and now y'are to be doomd by an impartiall Judge.

sp.speaker: Vinc.
sp.l: What meanes this Circumstance?

sp.speaker: Gisb.
sp.l: Know that a man consists of soule and body;
The one by Nature, the other by Justice rul'd;
So he is lesse then man that swerves from either,
And disobeyes these equall Governours.
What Nature might command I have perform'd;
Now Justice takes his place, true partlesse Justice,
That heavenly Names bestows upon us here.
That we like Gods might no Affection beare;
Which once agen commands unto the Barre
Those bloody murderers.

sp.speaker: Vinc.
sp.l: Strange and unheard of.

sp.speaker: Gisb.
sp.l: Stand forth you haplesse wretches, that have robd
A creature of her life, which to restore,
Would make the world turne bankrout; nay more,
You have robd Heaven of a soule, inforc'd her hence
Loaden with all her sinnes without defence;
Not given her time to shed one pennitent teare,
That might plead for her before that severe
And all-confounding Judge, with losse of breath,
You have repriev'd her soule to far • e worse death.
Lastly, you have felloniously usurpt
The sword of Government, violated Law,
And being borne Subjects, you have assum'd
The seat of death-inflicting Soveraigntie; for which
We doome you—Weake heart, why, doest thou faint?
Thou injurest me: You trayterous eyes, since that
You dare not see to doe such worthy Justice
On these wretches, I will blind and barre that light,
Whose partiall view doe make so few doe right;
Now know we doome you for this your horrid murder
To present Execution, and command
That where the fact was done, a Jibbit stand,
On which you both shall suffer forthwith; Officers away,
Your lives are forfeit in one houres delay.

sp.speaker: Vinc.
sp.l: Beyond all president!

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: For mine owne life,
'Tis justly forfeited, but to this creature
Vrania, not as she is my wife,
But thy daughter, the hope of thy name,
And wisht posterity, be pitifull.

sp.speaker: Gisb
sp.l: Thou beatst the Ayre, though all the world should fa • l,
Justice must be her selfe, beare equall sail.

sp.speaker: Vra
sp.l: Be patient gentle Love, since 'tis for thee,
I cannot thinke it is an Ill to die.
Father Farewell, your doome I will not grudge,
Above I hope to finde a milder Judge.

sp.speaker: Gisb.
sp.l: Away with em—Heaven on their soules have mercy.
Stay, let me embrace thee, thou perfect'st man
That er'e made Nature proud▪ Renowned Gisbert,
Loe as thou gavest unto thy Countryes good
Thy onely daughter, having no other gift
Worthy thy merit, I returne agen
Thy present, which to recompense with any
Other Benefit would speake us poore
And much ingratefull, in us they both shall live
With pardon, so receive them, then.

sp.speaker: Gisb.
sp.l: As a repreive sent to condemned men.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: In whom maist thou survive to endless dayes. As for this loathed Creature Hells Harbinger, this Bawd to sinne, her daughters losse shall take away her bodyes punishment, onely we banish her six miles from any City.

sp.speaker: Gul.
sp.p: I had rather be Carted six times about the City then live in the Countrey, unlesse your grace will make a continuall progresse.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Away with her, what meanes this sound?

sp.speaker: Vinc.
sp.p: It gives a signall to a Combata • t that has accus'd a stranger of foule lust with a knowne Shepheard.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Our selfe have heard so much, give him his oath.

sp.speaker: Vinc.
sp.p: Sweare by thy trust in Heaven thou comst not Armd, led on by malice, or in hope of gaine, but in the Justice of thy cause without eyther charme or guile.

div.stage: Enter Oswell, Alexis, Adelizia: Sigismund gazes on her.

sp.speaker: Osw.
sp.l: This Ile make good.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Administer the like Oath to the other.

sp.speaker: Vinc.
sp.l: Sweare by the equall powers, • o hope or confidence,
Doth raise thine Arme besides thine Innocence.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: I sweare, and if not truely, of Heaven I crave,
Instead of ayd, to send a shamefull grave.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Give signall to the fight.

sp.speaker: Sigis.
sp.l: Stay.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: What meanes our sonne?

sp.speaker: Sigis.
sp.p: This she, that brow, that eye, that face doth speake it, give me my Armour there.

sp.speaker: Catz.
sp.p: Give him his braines there, has most need of them.

sp.speaker: Sigis.
sp.l: Villaine, Ile teare thy soule out, if thou deferre one minute.
Divinest Beauty, oh let me kisse thy hand!

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: This accident confounds, speake gentle sonne.

sp.speaker: Sigis.
sp.l: And if I have a Being worthy you,
Deny not my request, or with my Brest
Ile naked thus oppose the traytor.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Thou hast thy wish fayre sonne, bring weapons forth,
Some fate directs him thus.

sp.speaker: Vinc.
sp.l: More Champions yet; what meane these strangers?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: To prove this Traytor a malicious villaine;
That Lady chast and free.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: The same cause moveth me to equall Armes.

sp.speaker: Sigis.
sp.l: You shall be damn'd, first; by my blood and Honour,
Who makes an offer to deprive this Arme
Of this fayre Conquest, drawes one on himselfe.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: They shall not, I must intreat you give free way unto his passion, being assur'd the hand of Heaven drawes him to end his life or misery.

sp.speaker: Leo: Sil.
sp.l: Shall we not have the Honour then?

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Our sonne has begd it, and it must be his.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: We'l free him from that danger.

sp.speaker: Osw.
sp.l: Vexation.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: How dare you being exild approach this place?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Though not from death this deed shall free one staine, know that our love to Justice, whose wrong erst lost our good names doth force us hither, this is trayterous Oswell.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Oswell, lay hands upon the Monster.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: This Adelizia king Valerius daughter,
To whose untimely fall that villaine brib'd us;
When this blest Shepheard that preserv'd her breath,
Redeemd our lives from a despised death.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Astonishment!

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Dread Soveraigne, accept this Beauteous Princesse, fair Ad • lizia by me preserv'd after her shipwrack.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Joy overcomes me, can Adelizia live?

sp.speaker: Adel
sp.l: That Letter speakes no lesse.

sp.speaker: Sig.
sp.l: I know you are the same, my love pursued in those spatious woods.

sp.speaker: • del.
sp.l: I am the same.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Thou hast reviv'd my sonne, restor'd mine age,
So many Blessings, Heaven I wish no more.

sp.speaker: Adel.
sp.l: If any good my Being brings with it,
This vertuous Shepheard well may challenge it.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Our love and high regard shall speake it freely.
To you we give your meanes and libertie, to thee.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Doe but command us we'l teare him peecemeale.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Though his desert to such extreames might sway,
We'l have no blood shed on our wedding day.
We doome him to perpetuall prisonment.

sp.speaker: Osw.
sp.l: Had I my 〈◊〉 you should all keepe your wedding day in hell.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: So lead him hence. Now faire Adelezia there remaines,
Onely thy free consent to accept my sonne.

sp.speaker: Sigis.
sp.l: I am her owne, the marriage Heaven begun,
When her blest sight restor'd me.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Speake gentle maide.

sp.speaker: Adel.
sp.l: Since Fate ordaines it so,
I like your sonne so well, Ile scarce say no.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Then lovely daughter, true Subjects, worthy friends,
I embrace you all, and here our woes all ends;
Which teacheth us, how ere vaine man may trust,
The end makes happy those onely that are just.
